Regional Technical Assistance Report
Project Number: 41571 
December 2007 
Supporting Strategic Knowledge Products and 
Research Networking
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CPS  –  country partnership strategy 
  CSPU  –  country strategy and program update 
  KPS  –  knowledge products and services 
  MOF  –  Ministry of Finance 
  PRC  –  People’s Republic of China 
  RETA  –  regional technical assistance 
  TA  –  technical assistance

NOTE
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
Vice President  C. Lawrence Greenwood, Jr., Operations Group 2 
Director General  H. S. Rao, East Asia Department (EARD) 
Deputy Director General  K. Gerhaeusser, EARD 
Team leader  D. Sobel, Senior Results Management Specialist, EARD 
Team member  M. L. Panlilio, Senior Economics Officer, EARD

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the governments of Mongolia and the People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) intensified a dialogue in 2006 on the need to add value to their 
development and economic expansion by strengthening the role of knowledge and innovation in 
their country programs. Since then, the ADB has taken systematic steps to place knowledge 
management,  and  the  creation,  improvement,  and  expansion  of  knowledge  products  and 
services  (KPS)1 in  the  mainstream  of  Mongolia  and  PRC  operations.  The  aim  is  to  help 
countries respond effectively and fully to the crucial importance of knowledge in accelerating 
economic development, and to plan and implement ways to enhance their knowledge resources. 
ADB’s East Asia Department has established a knowledge management unit and adopted a 
system of KPS programming and implementation. Improving knowledge products has become a 
key result area.  
2.  In 2007, ADB and the PRC embraced knowledge and innovation as a core theme in the 
draft country partnership strategy (CPS). During the Country Programming Midterm Review 
Mission, held from 10 to 13 April 2007 in Beijing, the Government of the PRC welcomed the 
strengthened  emphasis  on  KPS  as  an  important  pillar  of  ADB’s  assistance  program.  The 
Government  of  Mongolia  shares  ADB’s  view  of  the  importance  of  knowledge  in  attaining 
sustainable  development.  The  country  strategy  and  program  update  (CSPU)2 for  Mongolia 
(2007–2009)  supports  a  focused  strategic  approach  to  knowledge  through  its  non-lending 
program, with emphasis on institutional organization, efficiency of public service delivery, better 
coordination and monitoring, and strengthened results. The Fact-Finding Mission, conducted 
from  20  to  27  August  2007,  reached  agreement  on  the  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  and 
implementation arrangements for the proposed TA.3 The TA design and monitoring framework 
is in Appendix 1. 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  A trend that began in national economies in the early 20th century continues today—
increasingly greater value is being created from services than from industry or agriculture.4 The 
creation of value, whether economic or social, is being achieved through knowledge. National 
economies  are  becoming  more  knowledge-based,5 especially  in  terms  of  productivity  and 
growth. Leveraging information more effectively is especially important to improving productivity. 
Economic  competitiveness  now  depends  on  the  ability  to  transform  vast  quantities  of 
information  into  useable  knowledge,  and  to  deploy  that  knowledge  effectively  across 
organizations, market ecosystems, and economies. ADB has suggested that the pillars of a 
knowledge-based  economy  are:  (i) education,  including  a  skilled  work  force;  (ii)  national 
innovation  systems  in  the  fields  of  science,  technology,  research,  and  development; 
(iii) networks, including information and communication technology infrastructure, and social 
networks; and (iv) a suitable policy and regulatory environment. ADB builds these pillars through 
loan-related knowledge transfers that include (i) innovative designs; (ii) introduction of new 
technologies,  and  the  best  practices  embodied  in  ADB  lending  and  technical  assistance; 
(iii) policy research work by ADB staff; and (iv) sharing development experience in the region.  
                                                
1  Knowledge products and services (KPS) are analytical work such as sector studies, thematic assessments (e.g., 
poverty, gender), policy analysis, project preparatory work, country economic reports, and evaluation reports.

4.  The  government  and  nongovernment  think  tanks  and  private  research  institutes  in 
Mongolia, are not well developed. They have limited experience and resources, and cannot 
provide competent policy briefs to the Government. Government research institutions lack top-
quality  personnel  and  modern  management  systems.  Because  professors  have  had  more 
training abroad, the capacity is better at the country’s universities. Their policy research work is 
often  too  theoretical  to  meet  government  needs,  however,  and  they  need  to  expand  and 
improve applied research methodologies so they can respond to the large demand for policy 
analysis. In the PRC, the Government recognizes that policy research is a priority. ADB has 
traditionally focused on projects, and the PRC has accumulated a lot of project management 
experience. What the PRC needs now is more support for its policy response capacity. That 
requires examining the lessons learned in the developed economies, as well as a greater 
understanding of the constraints and conditions unique to the PRC. KPS in the PRC should be 
complemented by high-level dialogues through strategic conferences, seminars, workshops, 
and training. These will produce cross-fertilization of ideas across groups and disciplines, and 
help disseminate outcomes to broader audiences.  
5.  In the past, requirements for knowledge in ADB operations in Mongolia and the PRC 
were  met  mainly  through  advisory  technical  assistance,  regional  technical  assistance,  and 
economic, thematic, and sector work done by ADB staff to address priority issues. PRC-specific 
technical  assistance  facilities6 were  also  established  as  flexible,  quick-response  funding 
mechanisms for policy-oriented KPS needed to address emerging government priorities when a 
new TA would be impractical or too slow. New components could be identified at a later stage of 
TA implementation, thus improving results.  
6.  Other TAs involving several ADB departments have had direct knowledge or policy-
research  objectives.7 Themes  have  included  PRC-India  policy  collaboration,  strengthening 
research networking in South Asia, establishing knowledge hubs in East and Central Asia—on 
topics such as energy, environment, and regional transport and trade—and knowledge sharing 
and  learning  for  monitoring  and  evaluation  in  Asia.  An  ADB evaluation  study8 noted  that, 
although the vast majority of advisory technical assistance projects are rated satisfactory, they 
are not being used to their full advantage. ADB’s existing knowledge management framework 
stops short of (i) developing processes for extraction of value-added materials, (ii) developing 
knowledge products that provide new analytical insights, and (iii) developing feasible reform 
options. Lessons learned from earlier knowledge-oriented TAs point to the need to respond to 
government  requests  on  emerging  issues,  to  coordinate  and  communicate  across  a  large 
number of government and nongovernment agencies, and to disseminate knowledge effectively 
as it is generated. 
7.  Based on these requirements and experiences, Mongolia and the PRC agree that a 
mechanism is needed to develop—or create the capacity to develop—strategic KPS that can

and the dissemination of KPS through appropriate networks that include government, academic, 
and other research institutes. More interaction among Mongolia, the PRC, and regional experts, 
and wider distribution of research findings and policy applications, in Mongolia and the PRC, will 
help  the  countries  in  their  pursuit  of  knowledge-based  economies.  By  providing  KPS  and 
helping them build their capacity to create KPS, ADB will be their knowledge partner in this 
effort.
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The  impact  of  the  TA  will  be  more  effective  policy  development,  coordination,  and 
government decision-making in Mongolia and the PRC, based on the expansion and application 
of quality research. The TA will help develop policy and sector reforms that are consistent with 
key areas9 of the CPS or CSPU. The outcome will be increased strategic policy dialogue, more 
research  and  access  to  development  knowledge,  and  greater  collaboration  among  the 
government agencies and think tanks.10 The TA will serve as a facility for ADB to respond 
quickly to KPS requests from Mongolia and the PRC, and to be proactive in informing decision 
makers  on  emerging  strategic  policy  issues  and  in  disseminating  research  findings  and 
knowledge more widely.  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The key outputs will be: (i) studies and applied research publications, including policy 
notes, technical papers, good-practices studies, sector and thematic reports, and other special 
publications or flagship studies; (ii) translations of KPS into Mongolian, Chinese, and other 
languages,  as  required;  (iii)  electronic  databases,  websites,  and  other  internet-related 
dissemination  work;  (iv)  high-level conferences,  seminars,  workshops,  training,  and  other 
meetings; (v) increased interaction on development issues affecting Mongolia and the PRC 
among  both  regional  and  domestic  research  institutions  and  experts;  (vi)  publication  and 
dissemination of existing and new KPS based on user demand and needs; (vii) strengthened in-
house  ADB  capacity  to  provide  high-level  policy  advice  to  Mongolia  and  the  PRC;  and 
(viii) other activities supporting the development, management, and sharing of knowledge. TA 
activities will be overseen by ADB, in coordination with the ministries of finance in Mongolia and 
the PRC. In response to emerging KPS needs and the country situations, Mongolia, the PRC, 
and ADB may be flexible in choosing activities from the three components over the course of 
the TA.
10. Component 1: Strategic Knowledge Products. The governments of Mongolia and the 
PRC, with ADB, will identify strategic development issues to be given priority for research. 
These issues will be consistent with the goals of the CSPU and eventual CPS for Mongolia, and 
the CPS for the PRC, and have the potential to promote and raise awareness of knowledge and 
innovation. In Mongolia, for example, topics could relate to ADB’s traditional focus—health, 
education,  and  road  transport—but,  to  demonstrate  innovation,  also  involve  study  of  the 
practical applications of such research on town-based urbanization and in facilitating regional 
trade. In the PRC, the focus could move beyond road and railway transportation, energy, 
agriculture,  and  regional  cooperation,  to  examine  new  financing  modalities  for  rural 
                                                
9  For  example,  areas  include  (i)  inclusive  growth  and  balanced  development,  (ii)  resource  efficiency  and 
environmental sustainability, (iii) regional cooperation and public goods, and (iv) enabling environment for private 
sector development. 
10 Academia, research institutes, nongovernment organizations, and government research facilities.

4
development and energy savings. The component will include funding for the professional 
services of domestic and international experts who undertake research, and for the logistics 
related to the work of these experts and ADB staff. Also included will be funds for editing, 
translating, printing, and publishing (i) new KPS produced under this TA, (ii) KPS developed in-
house by ADB staff, (iii) KPS created under staff consultancies, and (iv) KPS produced under 
other past or current ADB-funded TA projects that may require additional expenditures for use 
by Mongolia and the PRC—the cost, for example, of reprinting an ADB publication for which no 
further resources are available under the TA that first funded it.  
11. Component 2: Research Capacity Planning and Building. The TA will develop plans 
for creating the capacity for applied research within a government agency, a university, a 
research  institution,  a  nongovernment  institution,  or  ADB,  and  include  training  and  other 
activities to help build this in-house capacity. In Mongolia, for example, this could involve the 
design of a master plan, including a resources scheme, to establish the capacity for policy 
research within the Ministry of Finance (MOF.) The strengthening of policy analysis at the MOF 
could  complement  a  project  under  consideration  by  The  Asia  Foundation  to  support  an 
independent  think  tank  in  Mongolia  capable  of  providing  policy  briefs  requested  by  the 
Government and other stakeholders. Given the PRC’s relative strength in research capacity, 
this component is expected to concentrate on Mongolia. Specialized capacity-building activities 
for the PRC could, however, also be considered. They could include developing research hubs 
for a strategic sector like energy savings. The TA will also support capacity- building activities to 
enable ADB staff to provide more effective KPS to Mongolia and the PRC. 
12. Component 3: Knowledge Sharing and Research Networking. This component will 
provide funds for publicizing and disseminating KPS developed under components 1 and 2. It 
will also support research networking activities. This will be accomplished largely through high-
level  conferences,  seminars,  workshops,  focus  groups,  training,  and  other  meetings,  and 
through the use of eminent independent experts and think tanks. A main goal of these activities 
is cross-fertilization of ideas across groups and disciplines.11 Networks of government and 
nongovernment research institutes will likely be convened to discuss and debate policies related 
to  specific  sectors  or  themes.  Given  limited  funds,  the  TA  may  concentrate  initially  on 
networking between each nation’s MOF and the research arms of its other ministries, and 
between these research arms and think tanks on those subjects in which MOF requests help. 
This component also includes (i) internet dissemination work, (ii) innovative modes of sharing 
knowledge  among  all  stakeholders  in  the  subregion,  (iii)  support  for  development  of  an 
electronic sectoral and thematic database in Mongolia and the PRC, and (iv) identifying the 
most qualified institutions and experts to carry out KPS activities. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The cost of the TA is estimated at the equivalent of $1,000,000. The TA will be financed 
on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The TA cost estimate is based on engagement 
of international and domestic experts; support for editing, translation, and printing of KPS; and 
associated  networking  and  knowledge  sharing—e.g.,  conferences,  seminars,  workshops, 
training—including  rental  of  facilities  for  policy  dialogue  and  consultations,  interpretation, 
equipment, transport and lodging, photocopying, logistical and administrative costs, website 
development, electronic databases, and other costs related to dissemination work. The detailed 
cost estimates are in Appendix 2.  
                                                
11 For example, a conference in the PRC bringing together provinces to discuss national road sector policy would be 
a suitable activity.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  ADB will be the Executing Agency of the TA, with ADB’s East Asia Department, Office of 
the Director General, working in collaboration with the respective MOFs of Mongolia and the 
PRC, which will be the implementing agencies for KPS topic selection, under arrangements to 
be agreed upon with ADB. Steering committees in Mongolia and the PRC will be established 
under the regional technical assistance, comprising key government ministries, think tanks, and 
ADB, to conduct quarterly meetings to identify priority policy issues, research requirements, and 
prominent scholars. Invitations will be issued to research institutions, visiting professors, and 
practitioners,  to  present  proposals  for  studies.  In  Mongolia,  the  steering  committee,  in 
cooperation with the economic policy advisor to the Prime Minister, will prepare an annual list of 
potential research topics to facilitate research work. In the PRC, there will also be an annual 
meeting, following the National People’s Congress in March, to identify the emerging issues that 
need attention.
15.  A  Working  Group  will  be  established  for  the  TA  within  ADB  to  advise  ADB’s 
representative on the Mongolia and PRC steering committees on proposed KPS initiatives and 
to approve logistical expenses related to KPS production and dissemination.12 The Working 
Group will develop and approve the ADB dissemination plan for KPS produced under the TA, 
and for KPS produced in-house by ADB staff or under other TAs and staff consultancies. The 
dissemination plan will identify the types, formats, and numbers of publications needed, the 
audiences, and the public relations activities. This plan will be coordinated with those developed 
by the Mongolia and PRC steering committees. 
16.  Steering  committees  will  screen  all  KPS  proposals,  following  agreed  criteria  and 
application  processes.  KPS  proposals  will  be  capped  at  $100,000,  unless  ADB  and  the 
implementing agencies agree to waive this ceiling for a proposal. Depending on the activity, 
funds will be disbursed by ADB through either the Executing Agency or the implementing 
agencies, which will liquidate expenses to ADB. Advance payment facilities will be established 
because many studies and conferences require funds in advance.  
17.  As the TA will be designed to flexibly address government requests over a two-year 
period, starting from February 2008 to January 2010, consulting services will be determined on 
a case-by-case basis for each activity. The consultants13 will be engaged by ADB in accordance 
with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). Proposals 
that provide honoraria to experts for KPS activities will use a competitive selection process 
acceptable to ADB whereby at least three individuals are evaluated according to educational 
background and relevant experience. Indicative roles for experts are described in Appendix 3. 
TA activities will be monitored and reports made available through the ADB website.
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis 
for Supporting Strategic Knowledge Products and Research Networking, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board. 
                                                
12 Logistical expenses for KPS and support for ADB in-house KPS activities will be approved by the ADB Working 
Group, not by the steering committees.  
13 Consultants could be individuals or institutions, and could include think tanks, academic institutions, research 
institutes, nongovernment organizations, and government research facilities.

13      Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  General 
1.  Consulting services will be determined on a case-by-case basis for each activity identified 
and approved by the steering committees1 and Working Group.2 The technical assistance (TA) will 
require inputs from international and domestic consultants in areas of expertise consistent with the 
policy priorities set out in the relevant country partnership strategy (CPS) for the People’s Republic 
of China (PRC) or country strategy and program update for Mongolia.3 Experts may be drawn from 
a  range  of  individual  consultants,  consulting  firms,  research  institutes,  think  tanks,  academic 
institutions, government  research  arms,  nongovernment  organizations,  and  the  private  sector. 
Experts will provide both analytical and operationally relevant inputs and recommendations—i.e., 
they may engage in academic research and applied research in such fields as policy applications 
and capacity planning. They will also help design knowledge-sharing activities, and innovative 
ways to disseminate recommendations from the strategic policy studies prepared under the TA to a 
variety of different audiences. 
B.  Applied Research Analysts (estimated at 30 person-months, international and national) 
2.  The consultants will be specialists in the identified areas of strategic policy research, and 
will be capable of creating, analyzing, synthesizing, transferring, publishing, and disseminating 
knowledge relevant to the needs and priorities of the governments of Mongolia, and the PRC, and 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB). Specific terms of reference will be drawn up on a case-by-
case basis as the steering committees and Working Group propose knowledge product topics, and 
identify the needed experts. Indicative tasks for the consultants include, but are not limited to, the 
following general areas: 
  1.  Component 1: Strategic Knowledge Products 
(i)  Assist the governments of Mongolia and the PRC, and ADB, to identify priority 
strategic  development  issues  for  research  that  are  consistent  with  the  country 
strategy and program update and eventual CPS for Mongolia, and the CPS for the 
PRC, and that have the potential to promote knowledge innovation. 
(ii)  Undertake specific research, as required, to address an identified policy issue or 
problem, develop new knowledge, or adopt a new knowledge or technology, for use 
in Mongolia and the PRC. 
(iii)  Provide succinct and practical recommendations on the immediate policy options 
available to Mongolia and the PRC in addressing constraints to their development, 
taking into consideration the sharing of experiences and ideas between Mongolia 
and the PRC. 
(iv)  Create  knowledge  products  in  the  relevant  format—i.e.,  studies  and  applied 
research  publications,  including  policy  notes;  technical  papers;  good-practices 
studies;  sector  and  thematic  reports;  and  other  special  publications  or  flagship 
studies.
                                                
1  Steering committees in MON and PRC will comprise government ministries, think tanks, and ADB to identify policy 
issues and research requirements and identify prominent scholars to carry out research. 
2  The Working Group within ADB will be established for the TA to advise ADB’s representative on the MON and PRC 
steering committees on proposed KPS initiatives and to approve logistical expenses related to KPS production and 
dissemination. 
3  The CPS for PRC is currently under preparation. The CPS for Mongolia will be prepared in 2008.

14 Appendix 3 
(v)  Organize translations of knowledge products into Mongolian, Chinese, and other 
languages, as required. 
(vi)  Develop an electronic sectoral and thematic database in Mongolia and the PRC, 
identifying  the  most  qualified  institutions  and  experts  to  carry  out  knowledge 
products and services activities. 
(vii)  Develop  other  electronic  databases  and  websites  where  knowledge  products 
produced under the TA can be housed and accessed by Mongolia, the PRC, and 
ADB, and carry out other internet-related dissemination work. 
(viii)  Help  organize  the  quarterly  meetings  of  the  Mongolia  and  the  PRC  steering 
committees, and provide assistance, as requested, to the ADB Working Group for 
the TA. 
(ix)  Supervise research support personnel, as needed, for administrative functions such 
as collecting data and information relevant to the research studies, and providing 
other  support  to  the  research  consultants,  the  Mongolia  and  the  PRC  steering 
committees, the ADB Working Group, and ADB’s East Asia Department, which will 
be Executing Agency for the TA. 
  2.  Component 2: Research Capacity Planning and Building 
(i)  Develop  plans  for  establishing  in-house  applied  research  capacity  within  a 
government agency, university, research institution, nongovernment institution, or 
ADB,  and  for  conducting  training  and  other  activities  to  support  such  capacity 
building.
(ii)  Assess  the  appropriateness  of  the  incentive  structures  in  existing  research 
institutions,  identify  constraints,  examine  successful  research  agencies  and 
institutions  in  and  outside  Mongolia  and  the  PRC,  and  recommend  relevant 
successful practices for possible adoption. 
(iii)  Propose  specialized  capacity-planning  and  capacity-building  activities,  such  as 
developing research hubs for strategic sectors, and increasing the exchange of 
experiences between Mongolia and the PRC. 
  3.  Component 3: Knowledge Sharing and Research Networking 
(i)  Identify networks of research institutes and think tanks in Mongolia and the PRC, 
noting which networks serve as coordinating centers for specific topics, and which 
research institutes have the technical skills and capacity to undertake the specified 
activities.
(ii)  Organize  and  conduct  appropriate  activities  for  sharing  of  knowledge  products 
between  Mongolia  and  the  PRC,  with  the  focus  on  lessons  learned  and 
recommendations for possible adaptation, where relevant. 
(iii)  Propose  and  help  organize  high-level  conferences,  seminars,  workshops,  focus 
groups, training, and other meetings, and through the use of independent, eminent 
experts and think tanks. 
(iv)  Organize  and  conduct  appropriate  activities  for  the  effective  dissemination  of 
findings of studies or for effective policy dialogue among stakeholders, i.e., establish 
contacts  with  stakeholders,  coordinate  workshops  and  meetings  with  relevant 
parties,  review  draft  studies  for  dissemination,  recommend  strategy  for 
dissemination, and provide inputs at various stages of TA implementation. 
(v)  Propose and develop internal networking activities within Mongolia and the PRC 
between  their  respective  ministries  of  finance  and  the  research  arms  of  each

Appendix 3  15 
country’s other ministries, and between these research arms and think tanks on 
those topics for which the ministries of finance request assistance. 
(vi)  Evaluate  the  need  for  a  common  knowledge  management  platform,  and  help 
establish one, if needed. 
  4.  Tasks Covering Components 1–3 
(i)  Liaise with identified research think tanks and organizations for effective delivery of 
outputs under the TA. 
(ii)  Propose,  prepare,  and  organize  knowledge  products  and  activities  on  policies 
related to regional cooperation between Mongolia and the PRC and networking 
among their think tanks. 
(iii)  Prepare draft agreements with research organizations and think tanks forming part 
of the research networks under the TA that could be tapped for future delivery of 
knowledge products. 
(iv)  Undertake other tasks as deemed appropriate by ADB’s East Asia Department for 
successful completion of the TA.
